heading: fcc to let cell callers pay
subheading: the federal communications approved a policy on thursday that will let customers who make calls to mobile phones foot the bill for air time. by joanna glasner
author: joanna glasner
text: a new ruling from the u.s. federal communications commission will make it easier for mobile phone junkies to lower their telephone bills. on thursday, the fcc voted to establish a nationwide policy that will allow mobile customers to pass on the costs of incoming calls.the move by federal regulators followed years of lobbying by the mobile communications industry, which says it could increase business by giving customers a wider array of billing options. fcc officials bought into the argument.``it will hasten the day when people start to look to their wireless phone as their primary phone,'' said fcc chairman william kennard.the proposed billing practice -- known as calling party pays -- is widespread for wireless users in europe and latin america, where the person who dials the mobile phone number commonly pays for the call.the billing system has yet to catch on in the united states, however, where mobile phone owners usually foot the bill for both incoming and outgoing calls. although federal law never prohibited the practice, phone companies weren't required to provide the service.that's about to change.in its thursday ruling, the fcc decided that the calling party pays service should be regulated at the federal level and not subject to splintered, state-by-state rules on local land-line telephone service.under the fcc's proposal, wireless carriers would be allowed to offer calling party pays as an optional service to customers. callers would be informed about charges through uniform recorded message to be worked out by the agency, carriers, state regulators and consumer groups.the proposal didn't include any regulation of the rates carriers could charge the caller. fcc commissioners asked for comments, however, on whether there is enough competition to keep those rates reasonable, since the caller wouldn't have a choice about the wireless carrier used by the person they called.wirelesscompanies expect that even with calling-party-pays available nationwide, many customers will still prefer to keep paying for both incoming and outgoing calls. one reason is that calls to mobile phone calls usually cost less for cell phone owners.another problem with calling-party-pays is that phone companies aren't always able to track down and bill the person who placed the call. so wireless phone users sometimes pick up the bill anyway.telecommunications analysts at the research firm yankee group say the fcc has underestimated how difficult it will be for local telephone companies to set up the back-end infrastructure to provide calling party pays billing.researchers are also predicting that the billing option won't get a huge following in the united states, partly because mobile phone users are already used to paying for incoming calls. currently incoming calls represent about 20 percent of all mobile phone calls, as compared to about 40 percent in europe, according to yankee group.still, supporters of the nationwide calling-party-pays policy say it treats wireless phones more like ordinary land-line phones and could make services more affordable for low-income users or people with prepaid plans.wireless carriers say the billing plans could also help them make money by boosting the number of incoming calls to mobile phones. reuters contributed to this report.
